reviewText:
I don't even know where to begin, but I'll try...
(Real long read, but want to make sure to steer you away from this terrible, terrible game)

EDIT: But first, if you’re here for the Steam Exclusive Deal? Dooon’t do it.
First, they’re treating you like brainless cattle. It’s NOT free DLC, you’re downloading nothing new. All it does is let you start with a level 35 Time Tracer (Very low level) and give you a bunch of TIMED cashshop goodies (They pretend that’s worth money, hence the ‘free’ part). That. Is. All. Nothing new or unique.
You’re not cattle to be milked like KOG loves to believe, don’t fall for this ‘free DLC’ ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.
And back to the review….

First - Cashshop.


It's a free to play, sure, but it fails absolutely miserably at handling its cashshop. Power, not convenience, is for sale. Just take a look at what you'll want for a new character:

Want to use more than 4 skills at once? 9$
Ditto items? 6$
Want a costume (greatly boosts PVP stats)? Anywhere from 15-32$
Do you want skill notes (greatly boosts skills)? 1.50$ a piece, can use up to 6
Want an overpowered pet? 4$
Want an overpowered mount? 23$

That's 60$ for a huge power boost nearly unobtainable ingame. In other words, apparently this game is so awesome, a single character should cost more than the price of a triple A game (Surprise, it’s not). That’s not even touching the hundreds of dollars you can spend going for overpowered +11 equipment
That alone should be giving you bad vibes, but to continue…


Second - Balance.


Short version: There is none.

Long version: Sigh…

KOG's idea of new content is a new, more broken character. That way people will go AWESOME" and pay $60+ in previously mentioned cashshop for their new broken character.
And then they release another
recommended: and repeat the loop for infinite money. New dungeons? Nope

reviewText: As someone with over 2000 hours clocked into this game, I can say without a shadow of a doubt that this is a pay to win game. You can travel through most of the game without cash, but if you wish to succeed at all in it, you will need cash. $10 for a repair scroll. $13 for a marriage (Note, the site only manages increments of 5, 10, 20 and 100 so anything odd numbered requires a larger than your desire purchase), as well as other 'interesting' payment methods. Such as if you wish to expedite your Hyper Skill work and just buy it, it's 550 KC, however, they don't dabble in pay what you need"
date: so you need to pay 10 just for that 550.\n\nThe PVP is by far one of the worst pvp systems I have ever had the sheer disgust of dealing with. It's almost 100% completely gear based. reviewText:
I love this game.. cute characters, nice combos, fun pass time.. But if you hate it, then.. Here~ Make an apple pie instead :3

Pastry

2 cups all-purpose flour

1 teaspoon salt

2/3 cup plus 2 tablespoons shortening

4 to 6 tablespoons cold water

Filling

1/3 to 1/2 cup sugar

1/4 cup all-purpose flour

1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon

1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg

1/8 teaspoon salt

8 cups thinly sliced peeled tart apples (8 medium)

2 tablespoons butter or margarine

1) In medium bowl, mix 2 cups flour and 1 teaspoon salt. Cut in shortening, using pastry blender (or pulling 2 table knives through ingredients in opposite directions), until particles are size of small peas. Sprinkle with cold water, 1 tablespoon at a time, tossing with fork until all flour is moistened and pastry almost cleans side of bowl (1 to 2 teaspoons more water can be added if necessary).

2) Gather pastry into a ball. Divide in half; shape into 2 flattened rounds on lightly floured surface. Wrap in plastic wrap; refrigerate about 45 minutes or until dough is firm and cold, yet pliable. This allows the shortening to become slightly firm, which helps make the baked pastry more flaky. If refrigerated longer, let pastry soften slightly before rolling.

3) Heat oven to 425°F. With floured rolling pin, roll one pastry round into round 2 inches larger than upside-down 9-inch glass pie plate. Fold pastry into fourths; place in pie plate. Unfold and ease into plate, pressing firmly against bottom and side.

4) In large bowl, mix sugar, 1/4 cup flour, the cinnamon, nutmeg and 1/8 teaspoon salt. Stir in apples until well mixed. Spoon into pastry-lined pie plate. Cut butter into small pieces; sprinkle over filling. Trim overhanging edge of pastry 1/2 inch from rim of plate.

5) Roll other round of pastry into 10-inch round. Fold into fourths and cut slits so steam can escape. Unfold top pastry over filling; trim overhanging edge 1 inch from rim of plate. Fold and roll top edge under lower edge, pressing on rim to seal; flute as desired. Cover edge with 2- to 3-inch strip of foil to prevent excessive browning.

6) Bake 40 to 50 minutes or until crust is brown and juice begins to bubble through slits in crust, removing foil for last 15 minutes of baking. Serve warm if desired.

reviewText: Let me list my problems with this game.\n\nThere is a significant pay-to-win issue in the game in the form of costumes and gear enhancements. Contrary to a relatively fair" free to play game model
date: Elsword's costumes (for a reason which is easily fathomable) give stats and overall power. As a result
recommended: this results in those who are willing to pay real cash having a significant advantage over individuals who do not. More to the point
hoursPlayed: Equipment enhancements
voteText: due to their nature of increasing stats via an increasing percentage per enhancement level (From a 1% stat increase at +1
helpfulPercent: 15% stat increase at +6~9 and a +30% stat increase at +9~11) results in a ridiculous power disparity between high-enhancement weapon wielders and low-enhancement weapon wielders. With the present average enhancement at +7
votesHelpful: people at +8 and higher will have a 15~100% base attack stat advantage in comparison to the average player.\n\nThe PvP system of this game
votesTotal: contrary to most individual opinions
votesFunny: is genuinely well-thought out and generally well made. This game's PvP is dependent on your ability to 'catch'- i.e.
commentsCount: hitstun your opponent and land a series of hits in the form of combos
column16: and repeat. Hence
column17: it is potentially possible for any character at any level to defeat any character and any level
column18: as long as one's skill level is higher than the other. On a clean
column19: basic flowchart
column20: I find this highly appealing.\n\nHowever
column21: there are several significant issues with this PvP system.\nFirst and foremost
column22: there is a signfiicant balancing issue between the many classes and characters you can choose in the game
column23: particularly with the more recently released character/classes. For those interested in said balance issues the PvP forums are the place to go.\nSecondly
column24: due to this game's frame rate being directly tied to your computer's performance level (i.e. general graphics and CPU power) and because your frame rate is directly tied to your character's input response speed (e.g. Attack/Movement/Jump speed) anyone with an inferior computing experience compared to the opponent will find themselves severely disadvantaged due to their character's slower response time- hence opening up far more opportunities for your opponent to catch you whilst simultaneously reducing your number of opportunities to catch you opponent.\nThirdly
column25: this game's matching system is a peer-to-peer system
column26: which directly connects your IP to the opponent's IP. As I am an Australian and this game is based in America
column27: naturally most of my opponents are individuals across the whole pacific ocean
column28: resulting in horrible latency. This results in delayed response times as hits and actions on your screen may not register on the opponent's screen
column29: as is the same for your opponent to you as well. This results in a horrible PvP experience for both parties.\nFinally and most importantly
column30: the above enhancement system comes into play in PvP as well. As in PvP
column31: you can be matched up with anybody and anyone regardless of character level/class/equipment enhancement level
column32: anyone with equipment of lower enhancement level will find themselves highly disadvantaged in many matches due to their equipment being inferior to their opponent's.  As a result
column33: the gear discrepancy between players becomes ridiculously high as one progresses up in PvP rank
column35: regardless of their skill level they will find it extremely difficult to defeat their opponents who have far superior equipment. For instance
column36: a +7 weapon wielder may find themselves hitting for 3-digit damage on their opponents whilst they hit back for over 4~5 digit damage.\n\nHence
column37: the PvP system at its present state is highly undesirable to play without significantly increasing your character's power level
column38: which in turn requires (and will inevitably require) real cash investment
column39: i.e. as the common phrase is
column40: it will require you to buy power.\n\nOn the flip-side of the coin
column41: the PvE system of this game serves as several dungeons in which you clear stages after stages of monsters
column42: culminating to a generally difficult last-stage boss. However
column43: after a while these bosses become walkovers
column44: and it becomes boring to grind these after a while. Challenges exist in the form of solo Secret Dungeons and Henir Challenge modes. Although these are indeed interesting
column45: they harshly punish you for failing in them as the former consumes rare items for entry
column46: and the latter will only provide rewards for entry only once (i.e. if you enter and die in the first few stages
column47: you won't be able to get any rewards for the rest of the day). This also results in significant time and power investment.\n\nWould I recommend this game? No. really
column50: that's only once you reach the end game and you have sufficiently invested enough time and money in order to establish your character's power and place in the Elsword world
column51: as I have done so. I genuinely do not recommend this game for anyone with insufficient time or money on their hands."

reviewText:
I've played this game for god knows how long (roughly 3 years). I feel I should post a review.

Jist: Play one of 9 (soon to be 10) characters, with 3 different and slightly-to-very unique playstyles on each. With gameplay that is a mix between Smash Bro's, a traditional fighter, and traditional MMO.

So lets hit hard with the Pros and cons.

Pros:•Core gameplay is extremely enjoyable
•Variety variety variety
•The aesthetic is very pleasing, even though the whole play your manga" original tagline is nowhere to be seen

Cons:•Pay2win
•Pay2win
•there is very little actual content
•there is very little actual balancing. With the arrival of PvP Season 3 proving it in spades

reviewText: This game made me hate the now typical practice in not only Free to Play" games
date: but in most MMO's in general.\n\nI looked into this game a couple of years ago because I wanted something simple and easy to jump in/jump out whenever I wanted to "play" a game but not really play a game.  You know
recommended: do something to kill time until other obligations spring up or if I can't decide what other game I want to play instead.   I treated this game as a snack; something to enjoy in the meantime before the real meal comes up.\nAt first I was pretty happy.  It was nice
hoursPlayed: colorful
voteText: and simple.  And despite the atrociously generic characters (little girl with a big sword

no skill.  Just a whiny kid with his daddy's money.

Games like this are an embarrassment.  If you want to make a Free to Play game

reviewText: Got nothin much to say except I CAN'T... STOP... PLAYING... THIS ADDICTING GAME!!!! Fast paced side-scrolling hack and slash action complemented with an amazing variety of character classes, each with their own unique specialties that make them stand out, beautifully rendered background environments (since this is a side scroller) almost like an amazing artist just painted the whole thing with awesomeness and HOLY FREAKIN HELL!!!!... THE MUSIC IN MANY PARTS OF THIS GAME IS INCREDIBLE!!!!... I Just have some minor issues with this game... Stamina bar and tedious last class change quests and skill unlock quests... ( DAMN YOU AND YOUR ERRANDS CAMILLA!!!! DX)... Overall I would REALLY recommend this game to anyone that loves either good locales, good music, or some of the best side-scrolling gameplay Ive seen in my life... If you feel tempted to try, me and my Deadly Chaser will see ya in glorious PvP! (unless you face a Dimension Witch or an Infinity sword were against those either you dodge everything or you're freakin screwed... or just put a giant amount of unexpected burst on them like I do XD)

reviewText:
Product received for free

As someone who's played Elsword for a long time, I must note that Elsword has gone down a few leagues in the last few years in terms of playability. reviewText:
Don't let my time spent on this game fool you. I've been on board since Raven's release and it's been quite a roller coaster in terms of my opinion of this game up until now.

Elsword is a great game, don't get me wrong. The mechanics are solid, I haven't run into many glitches, and the general feeling of the game when playing is unique. Being a 2D fighting game, scrolling is to expected when it comes to dungeons. Elsword does it very well. Each dungeon has its own theme and get more fun as the game progresses. With the addition of fields, players have an alternative to obtaining EXP. PvP itself also rewards players with EXP, but in much smaller doses. Skills are flashy, each playable character feels unique, and overall, the game is pretty easy to pick up.

However, some key things set this game back two steps whenever it advances one. Mechanics are solid but latency issues and ping play a large factor in being able to PvP well. More often than not, I find myself dying to lag than skill, even when the other person is better anyway. I've won my share of lag matches, and I always feel bad when a genuinely good player gets beaten because of the awkward connection. Dungeons rehash a lot of the mobs. Certain effects can bolster and change a mob, but for the most part, it just takes more time to kill it. Speaking of which, every dungeon's boss save for the secret dungeons' are extremely easy to kill. It takes two to four 200-300mp skills to down most of the bosses. Some dungeons are too long, especially toward levels 30-40, and feel as though they are just intended to burn precious stamina. Killing mobs in fields also costs stamina, but that was very minor in my opinion. The PvP matchup system runs by what seems to be just ranks. This can cause a lot of problems as some high level players who have already attained high ranks lose matches on purpose and derank" in order to climb back up and farm for AP

reviewText: As a veteran of this game for almost four years, i can safely say this game does indeed have potential, but wastes it in alot of areas, the game requires necessary grinding for a good amount of skills, and the pay wall in this game is ENORMOUS. Unlike other games, Elsword locks both four skill slots off, and extra pages in the skill tree, both of which are nearly 20$ apiece. The game also does indeed have a problem with class balancing, and the developers refuse to listen to the american playerbase for opinions regarding buffs/nerfs, listening only to the korean playerbase. This game is indeed fun, but that will only last at most a few weeks before you start to become bored with the game or play with friends. If you do indeed like grinding, forced halting of your gaming due to the stamina system that is implemented, and severe balancing issues, than this is for you. Otherwise, i say skip out on Elsword, and look for some other game.

reviewText:
This can be an extremely addicting game, if you give it enough time to do so. Right in the beginning, you choose from a decently large variety of characters. To be honest, it's not really that great until you hit level 15 and can start your job change. A job change basically means you get more skills, a new look, and better stats. There are, however, both pros and cons to this game which I will also review.

Pros:> Lots of potential time to put into it
> Variety in characters
> Different playstyle, even in just one character
> PvP can be based more off of strategy than pure strength
> Lots of people - lots of friends
> Community is, for the most part, pretty good. Better than most.

Cons:> CAN be pay to win (The game's gold currency (ED) can be used to buy items that normally cost real money)
> Trading could possibly make you lose your ED
> Broken economy
> Unbalanced characters (Though, there are character rebalances every so often)
> PvPers who rage when they lose

Final verdict:It's a great game and definitely worth a try. Try not to be too discouraged by it being a bit slow in pace up until level 15 (which you could easily get in 30 minutes) and the broken economy. The variety in characters and even variety within each character should keep you busy for a LONG time. It's easy to make friends, because a lot of people are pretty friendly.

reviewText:
Warning! This review is long. Like, REALLY long. Do not click on this review unless you're willing to read a lot.
The gist:
This game is a trap. Stay away while you still can.

Intro:
If there's anything one should gather from my rather long playtime for this game, it's that this game is rather addicting. Don't get me wrong. There ARE some enjoyable bits in this game. I wouldn't have come back to this game after six months and rediscovered all the bad bits if there wasn't. But, yes, there are quite a few problems I have with this game that keep me from recommending it to anyone (or at least, anyone that  I'd respect  I know).

Gameplay (PvE):
If you've seen any of the trailers or read any other reviews for this game, you probably already know what the gameplay is like. You're at the leftmost side of a level, you go right, hitting anything that looks at you funny until they fall over, until you reach the end and get teleported to another, seemingly identical level. Well, maybe I shouldn't be so harsh. Some of the levels DO seem like they're set up rather well and the combat is rather engrossing. Armed with combos, special attacks, and super attacks (I know there aren't any moves called that, but whatever), the player can very easilly feel like he's a badass fighter in an action anime, running/flying around the screen hitting/slicing badies until finally blowing them up with a large explosion.

Until, of course, they realize the enemies are collectively about as threatening as a one-legged spider with brain damage. The enemies in this game are either legally blind or incredibly stupid because they only seem to acknowledge your presence when you're either right next to them or hitting them across their stupid heads. And when they do notice you, they perform their telegraphed attack once before either forgeting about you or walking slowly towards you. The exception to this behavior is the boss enemies, who have a better grasp on the idea of focussing on players but feel they need to more obviously telegraph their attacks to be fair.

Again, the levels do seem like they're well-made, so these problems with the enemies wouldn't seem so bad if one needed to visit each level only once. Is that the case? No. Levels will have to be visited three, and later even four, times before being allowed to the next one. And that's even assuming you're the right level, because otherwise the game just tells you to level up more, and since levelling up is so tedious, especially at higher levels, it won't be long before you're so familiar with levels that you could draw them on paper while blindfolded (this is assuming you're following the story, of course, and not just playing levels, but since levelling up takes so much grinding, especially later in the game, you might as well).

What also doesn't help with this tedium is the music. I've read some reviews where people have praised the soundtrack, calling it beautiful and epic and the like. And I have to say, yes, the music is rather wonderful...... for the first fifteen seconds anyways, because after that it just loops over again. Even the most beautiful tune in the world is going to sound annoying and overplayed after looping it every half a minute. Add this to the already grating grind settup and what would just be a minor annoyance to my ears suddenly turns into the music I hear in my nightmares.

Of course, a good way to break this tedium would be to play the levels in a party. Yes, this is an MMO after all, and thus you're given the option to play levels with up to three other players. In fact, the game actually encourages it (In a way that I'm not too fond of, but it honestly doesn't get me angry enough to talk about it.). Unfortunately, the only form of communication that the game provides is a text chat, which does not go well with the fast-paced action prevalent in the gameplay. As a result, playing in a party can usually be equated to a giant cluster♥♥♥♥ of screams, explosions, and screen shaking.

Overall, I'd give the whole PvE aspect of the game a miss.

Gameplay (PvP):
Now, in my opinion, this is where the game truly shines. One of the problems I had with PvE was the non-threatening enemies, and replacing them with one enemy who can actually outsmart you certainly fixes that. And the fast-paced gameplay is right at home in this mode, creating moments where the difference between victory and defeat lies within a nanosecond. I've had matches where both I and, I suspect at least, my opponent were sweating bullets throughout. Matches where I felt like I had to actually contact them and thank them for providing me with such an amazing fight.

What's unfortunate is that I can count the amount of matches like this that I've actually had in Elsword on one hand. It seems like for every opponent pitted against me at the same level as me, there were about fifty who were forty levels below me and fifty who were forty levels above me. This can be blamed on Elsword's rather bad matchmaking system.

So, to summarize on actual gameplay, look somewhere else.

Community:
I remember a review talking about how the people in this game are really friendly and playing in the community is fun and how it's so easy to make friends in this game. I can only assume that they were an extrovert and thus able to make friends anywhere else, because, for an introvert such as myself, the majority of the people that I seemed to get acquainted with were people that I wanted to reach through the computer screen and punch in the nose. But maybe I'm wrong on this. Maybe all those annoying players were just a small fraction of the player populace, and the majority of the players on this game are nice, decent individuals who don't get upset when you tell them that no, you don't want to friend them just because you said something remotely funny while in a level. But if that's the case, then it certainly isn't obvious to me.

Management:
While I don't seem to agree with them on some things, the creators behind this game do seem to take care of it. Bugs and issues are practically nonexistent, and updates are rather frequent. They also hold events for their players. No matter what day, there's always some kind of event going on in Elsword (which, to me, totally undermines the whole POINT of an event, but whatever.), where any player online during it can get a special item only available then and there.

It just feels as though they're focussed on all the wrong things. It seems like, for every update made to balance the game or fix issues, there's about twenty updates made to add a new costume to the in-game store.

Oh, yes, they have an in-game store, where things in it cost real money. Some items even have additional stat increases when worn. Now, debate can be made over whether or not these increases have any real impact on gameplay, but frankly, it's the fact that there are stat increases in the first place that pisses me off. There's more to be said about this feature, but I feel plenty of people have already harped on it enough that anything I say here would just be a rehash.

Closing:
This isn't a game meant to bring in new players. This is a game meant to keep old members mindly interested and not think about any other way they could be spending their time, turning the grindfest that is its gameplay into a reasonable sacrifice for getting this totally new accessory only available on a certain day and then doing the same exact thing the very next day. It becomes very easy for one to become addicted to the promise that is a free accessory. The only reason that I got out when I did was because I realized what was happening.

But others are not so lucky. Even today, there are those stuck in this endless loop with little hope for escape. Do not join them. Stay away while you can.

reviewText:
Elsword in itself, is actually a pretty repetitive game. Frustrating and basic.
However, having said that. It clearly has some form of enoyable charm that keeps players coming back for more, with the fast paced crazy combat, intense PVP action and overall captivating competitive gameplay, the game clearly can keep a player entised for hours on end, for weeks and weeks to come.

Though there is a cash-shop that holds a lot of important things, such as slot expansions and inventory space. The game is not only playable without having to pay a single thing. You're more than likely going to find yourself being able to justify making purchases within the game, as you'll play it that often and enjoy it that much.

reviewText:
Ignore my play time. I have played this game since Closed Beta in 2011. I partially did not want to write this review but I grew tired of the bullcrap this game has gone through.

The game was fun.

Fast forward to 2015.

I'll be honest. Grand Chase can't even compare to the amount of pay to win that this game has, and that says a lot. In order to stand a chance in PVP, you have to sacrifice money. Costumes have stats in them and are extremely overpriced. A full set can cost you between $25-$31.

Everyone and their cats in SSS ranks will have a Ring of Fury(aka Ring of Free Combo) which costs $8, and/or a +11 weapon, which there is little way of upgrading it that far without forking the money over. Magic Necklaces are a necessity, which again, costs $8. Don't even bother with Ice Burner sets because that's a huge money sink too. PVP Skill only applies when both sides spend enough money, and have a good connection with each other.

Elsword's Netcode is even worse than Grand Chase, as it's very common to run into players who lag, ignore your hitstuns and walk out of your combos. Even back then when the game was only  restricted to only NA and Oceanic players, lag was still common in PVP.

The events we had lately are either cash shop, or just useless. There is little incentive to even bother participating in many of them. Especially our current halloween event where there is no way to maximize the rewards you get without cashing.

Character balance is atrocious. It seems that KOG doesn't care about character balance, as each character that gets released gets more and more overpowered. Older characters, from Elsword to Eve(except for Runeslayer) will have a very hard time standing a chance against newer characters in PVP. They take very long to get to balancing anyway.

I'll admit, I did cash, but not frequently. But until KoG steps up their ♥♥♥♥, I'm not going to give them my money. And the more they force me to cash, the less incentive I have to play the game anymore.

Don't get me wrong though. Elsword is still a great game, and very fun as long as you play casually and not take the game seriously. PVP is an absolute joke for reasons stated above, so just ♥♥♥♥ around. If you want to play a bit seriously, there are some guilds out there that have developed the competitive scene, but like I said, you're going to have a hard time standing a chance in PVP without spending some money.

For those who want to play Elsword, be warned that you're going to have to use the cash shop at some point in your gameplay. It's a necessity.

reviewText:
Awesome game and addictive. A very good game that has jrpg elements in terms of gameplay. Can be a bit repetitive at times but overall it is a great game!

Now after playing more than 400 hours, I can say that even though i have spent money on the game, there are still many other factors such as skill that play an even bigger role than pay to win issues. As much as having a super cool costume, magic necklace, and a ring are important, they are NOT essential in the game. As much as there are people that spend so much money that it is impossible to beat them, the chances of facing those people are pretty low. There are a few cash issues invluding the ridiculous item mall prices but again, you dont have to pay to win. Its just nice and I still believe that Elsword is a great fast-paced side-scrolling MMORPG.

Gameplay:
Gameplay wise, the dungeons are nice and graphically designed beautifully with a mix of monsters for each different major area. Each dungeon has unique bosses that are designed to not be total walkovers. Even though once you get to level 55+ there is a bit of level grinding, with the constant addition and promotion of new characters, Elsword is a very good game. On the other hand, the PvP community is practically brain-dead with sore losers and rage quitters. Since you have to pay $9 for extra skill slots for the in game (you start with 4 and the skill slot gives you 4 more) they constantly call you a spammer. Also, level difference plays a huge role as players level 65+ often have end game equipment that makes others look like they dont do damage.


Overall : 9/10
voteText: 38 of 54 people (70%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
OVERVIEW

Elsword is a 2.5D MMORPG and is developed & published by KOG Studios. These company were known for making a really great 2D MMORPG called Grand Chase. This game is basically a spiritual successor to Grand Chase. Despite this game being received critically acclaim by both critics & users,the game suffer from repetitive gameplay and incoherent decisions that the developer made lately such as dungeon no longer drop skill notes and you are force to spend real money to buy it. However does that mean you should avoid this game at all cost ? Not really because this game has it own unique charm put into it. The server is heavily populated ever since the released of Add.

GAMEPLAY : 7/10

When you start off the game. Instead of being able to create your own character,you are given to choose a gender class locked character. While this might be a downside for some people,each of this character have a unique background story and different fighthing style.

Tutorial doesn't explain much about the game so you left wondering what you must do.

There is two ways you can level up,either by training in field or by playing dungeon with a bunch of random people.

Level progression is balanced ( you gain don't level extremely fast and slow at the same times ) but skills progression is extremely linear.

Tree skills only offer 2 different sets of skills and optional skills for you to choose,once you choose one,you cannot choose the others unless by using skills resets.

Another downside would be you only can assign 4 skills & 3 items slots so if you want to expand them then you need to buy using real cash in the item mall.

Quest can be extremely repetitive at times since it required you to play the same dungeon 3-5 times in order to progress to the next one.

Another problem would be the stamina bar. If you stamina bar reach zero,you couldn't get any experience points killing monster or completing dungeons. I don't understand why the developer think would be a great idea to implement a facebook like game stamina feature. You only get unlimited stamina during Friday-Sunday.

In-game money is not difficult to earn considering the item drop rate is quite high and you able to sell off you items in market too ( you don't need to use real cash to set up your own market ).

GRAPHICS : 9/10

By far one of the best 2.5D MMO graphics i seen so far.

The gorgeous artstyle and colorful visual impressed me a lot. Both the character and the monster design look pretty appealing.

One minor issue i have is that there is seem to be a lot of clipping issue when you fully equip your character with rediculous gear especially when two people stand together at the same area.

Different segment of area have different looks on them so you won't have to see the same repeatable background.

The interface is quite ok i would say while at the same time it a clutter mess and you can't customize it.

AUDIO : 9/10

Wide variety of soundtrack you going to listen as you progress far into the game. A lot of them sound like it comes from the Tales series game which had outstanding soundtrack.

All the characters in the game have Korean voice ( only when you initiate a skill they will speak in English ) and they are all well done ( some of the voice suite very well to all the playable characters ).

Some of the sound effects sometimes acts weird if you heard multiple critical strike.

Nevertheless i don't have much problem with the sound effects.

LONG-LASTING APPEAL : 7/10

For a 2.5D games,it provide sufficient fun for you to keep playing.

There is PvE,PvP,marriage,guild system as well as raid boss. Even though you level your character to max level,you can still choose to play other characters to test his/her ability & playstyle.

There is a new event every 2-4 weeks depending on how the current event last.

FINAL VERDICT : 8/10

While the gameplay fall short and there is many restriction within the game,i say give it a shot just to try out the gameplay mechanics considering it rare to find a 2.5D ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes.

It add a ton of fun if you could introduced a friends to join with you in playing this game.

It pretty addictive once you get used to the combat mechanic since it fast paced and well executed.

Oh and the player base of this game is pretty strong especially during weekend.

If you wondering if the game is pay 2 win,it actaully not. Only pay 2 win aspect i see is the additional skill & items slots you have to purchase but that is a minor issue and it optional.

Just stay away from PvP and focus entirely on it PvE. From there you gonna have a lot of fun in this game.

GRADE : B ( Great )

reviewText:
This game is absolutely awful, the older, original characters (Elsword - Eve) are completely outclassed by any of the later characters (with some minor exceptions). Therefore, if you like competitive PvP at all your best bet is going to be 1 or 2 classes, Add and Luciel at the moment.

Additionally, if you aren't in NA you may experience Elsword's Laggers, you will be staring at your screen watching someone warp around everywhere while their skills buffer randomly and end up killing you, fun.

The leveling is trash, it consists of doing the same dungeon 3 times, once on any difficulty, again on hard and again on very hard, for EVERY dungeon. Once you get up to skill notes and job changes they consist of grinding the same dungeons sometimes upwards of 20 times or paying $5 USD.

Which brings me to the cash shop, sure it's a free to play game but, it may as well not be, you start off with a ridiculously small inventory which you have to pay about $2 USD to expand by 8 slot, 8 SLOTS, to top it off you need to buy these for every one of the inventory cateregories : Special, Inventory, Consumable, Item, Quest, you'd need to pay $10 USD just to upgrade each of those inventories by a measly 8 slots (not enough, so you more have to spend about $30 USD just go get enough inventory space). Then there's the costumes, they cost about $30 USD each and if you want to play competitive PvP good luck without a costume, also, if you want to play Luciel you need 2 costumes so $60. The worst part is: costumes and inventories aren't shared across characters so, that $30 USD you just spent on your main character's inventory, yep, you need to spend another $30 for every other character you want to play on,

Please don't play this game, it's Nexon's second Maplestory and is nothing but a shameless attempt to grab as much $$$ as possible.

Yes, It doesn't say I've played elsword on steam, but off steam, i've had over 3 years of gameplay.
This game is EXTREMELY fun, it is a great game but, i cannot recommend it due to the overpriced pieces on the NA server. It'll take around a whole month of playing to get a good top piece, just buy dungeoning. The only other way your gonna get that is by spending alot of damn money for the piece. Some of the pieces are worth over 100$, just with in-game money that'd take years to get.

THE PVP IS COMPLETELY UNBALANCED. All the characters in the game are just not balanced. They have their cons and pros, but some characters, only have pros, no cons at all. Some even only have cons considering how stupidly weak they are. Onto the pay 2 win topic again, every expensive top piece gives stats, you need a whole set for more stats, you need money to get +11, probably over 100$ just to ATTEMPT.

If your glad to spend alot money on a game. Go right ahead, and you'll have one FUN time in this game. OTHERWISE, don't even bother downloading, getting the highest rank in the game probably will require you to spend around 500$. Getting to level 70 isn't as hard as it used to be.

The only good part in the pay 2 win scene in this game is, Elsword even gives chances to get some pretty good weapons, for instance, i spent nothing and got probably 15$ worth of items without even an event. Events give you the chance to get new and cool sets.

Overall my rating is 9/10 to the game. But unfortunately spending is the only way your gonna enjoy it.
THIS IS NOT A FREE TO PLAY GAME!

reviewText:
Probably not worth your time.
If you like anime, some fan-service, sidescrollers, and grinding you'll be fine.
The Elwiki[www.elwiki.net] is a great resource if you're going to play.

I've been playing on and off for a long time.

The game makes a ridiculous effort to cockblock my attempts at progress. There's a stamina bar that limits how many monsters that can be killed in a day (it's manageable, especially with unlimited stamina weekends), but more importantly the EXP rates screw you over around level 45. I've been forced to grind several times in between dungeons around Velder for that reason, and it appears at the same spots on every character.

The progression itself doesn't feel very spectacular. You only get a skill every five levels which isn't too often when the cap is 70. Once you finally do get a variety of skills, you're locked to only using four at a time unless you pay $10 for an expansion. Changing jobs is what pathes the way to more skills, but it also gives you new combos to use in addition to your character's base ones. The problem here is that most of these combos can be impractical to use, so having more than one of a character can feel incredibly repetitive.

You mostly play the game by using combos. You also have to practice catching opponents in PvP and knocking them down wastes a good opportunity. Knocking down monsters reduces the damage they take and they may retaliate with a strong attack. Combos are pretty easy to do in PvE, especially since you can just obliterate the first 20 dungeons without a care. btw don't solo. Love yourself (and your stamina). Monsters tend to be more aggravating than they are challenging.

The art is pretty and the outfits have a unique style, but the characters have been driven to almost exclusively fan-service. This is most apparent in the recent customization options (cash only) that have appeared in the Korean server. Most (if not all) of the new female art is sexualized.

There haven't been many efforts to upgrade the anime" quality to the game. They've stuck to the same assets they've had since the beginning which is ironic when I see ads saying "Play your manga!" as if that were the main appeal.

The characters weren't amazingly unique but they had their own things going for them. Effort has clearly dropped in development

reviewText:
I honestly have nothing good to say about this game.

- Gameplay, which is supposed to be focused on Combos, feels incredibly lacking. Don't expect anything more demanding than Z+Z+Z+Z+X.

- Graphics. Full 3D should be a good thing, right? Nope. Especially when you see the same low-poly 'Bob The Builder' blocks being copy-pasted from dungeon to dungeon.

- Deisign. Outfits should be an incredibly tempting 'must-buy' because of how good they look. In Elsword, most outfits consist of White, Black, and an 'Accent'. Or worse: PlayBunny, Demon, Angel, Oriental.

- Sounds. I had to turn this off. Battle should consist of the sound of metal colliding and wood breaking...not whoopie cushions being let loose in a vat of butter.

- Music. I certainly don't remember any of it, so I went on Youtube and listened to the tracks. None of them have a 'wow' factor...and they almost feel copy-pasted.

- PvE. Pretty boring and really to easy to max out. There really isn't that much challenge out there. As I typed this, I even forgot it was playing in the background...wow.

- PvP. Hope you spent money if you actually want to win. With regenerating MP, talent can only get you through so much before you end up stun locked or one shotted. Especially when LuCiel gets their 2nd job...

- World HUB. This really bothers me because it feels like they're just trying to stretch out the gameplay as well as give you some reason to purchase a Mount. A Mount in a sidescroller. Think about it: $. You can also spend $ traveling from HUB to HUB. Even more bothersome, the World Map is accessible anywhere...so why aren't the two of them tied together instead of being weird seperate entitites?

Honestly, Grand Chase S2 was as good as this genre was going to get. Elsword is your typical Korean MMO: No originality, hand holding grind, and a constant squeeze for cash and ideas from the community. If you go into Elsword and find yourself thinking that this experiance could be better, then go hunt down a Grand Chase private server. FGC.

Obviously, I'm bitter because KOG failed to improve upon Grand Chase because they wanted to focus on Elsword.

reviewText:
Ive been playing this game for 3 or so years and ive enjoyed every second of it to be honest.
Pros:
+you can play as 10 selectable characters each with their unique fighting style.
+good way to waste your time and day.
+gameplay can be addicting.
+there are some nice people in the community.
+you can have some fun in pvp
+There are some really fun classes you can try out.
+also the game introduces a tutorial for new players so they wont be as lost.
+sparring mode can be used to fight with other players or just talk and have fun

Neutral:
*In my opinion the game can be more of a dating website at some point. In sparring I see many men/woman(rarely woman) try and get a date.

cons:
-pvp can be aggrivating. especially with a lot of salt tossed around in the arena. If you constantly pvp and are fragile in feelings ( ; -; ) then be advised to be careful.
-The game is mostly pay to win" as they call it. If you wanna look badass/sexy your gonna have to pay for it. a single costume costs about 30 dollars or more not including accesories. prepare your wallet.
-the community has only gotten worse over the years. the game is mostly filled with people who want to date or perverts(*cough* me *cough*. like 90% of the game is nothing but perverts. There are nice one's. I do admit that. Ive met lots of decent people and friends. Even my ex said it. she told me one time. -pvp can be a constant aggrivation as well. if your the rage hard type (like me) then expect to rage your heart out.
-tutorial can get annoying once you already played the game for so long that you already know how things run.

reviewText: Product received for free\n\nBack when this game was young, I'd say the characters were more fun to play. (Actually required a brain) Now? So many people are playing the characters that don't. This game (PvP wise) is more class focused. The classes that are pretty much easy and dumb to play are Add (DE and LP) , Ara, Elesis (GM mostly), Chung (IP), Lu/Ciel, and Eve. Although, Eve damage is more balanced in sparring. She's legitimately dumb in arena. So if you want to win A LOT, play a character that doesn't require a brain or minimum work. If you were to put the best LK vs the best DE player, LK would lose. Too many people play easy classes. What's the fun in that? It's horrible for those that plays a character that require more thinking and game plan. If this game were to make the old character more powerful to withstand those easy classes, it would be a lot more fun. The gear in this game are fine. Yes, even with +12, and +11. It's purely based on your class and how good you are with them. But if you're playing a class that requires more thinking, no matter how geared and skilled you are, you will lose to the easy class that is geared and skilled too. Not to mention that this game requires Player to Player connection. This means that if you live in Australia, fighting a player that's in the U.S, you both will experience delay. Some classes are more lag proof than other classes, so you may be at a disadvantage. Surprising Fact: Not a lot of people know about this. You would have to PvP on a class that's hard to play to understand this. (Class vs Class case) P.S I'm a CBT player and a KR player. I recently just switched from the actual client to Steam client, just to write a review for this game. Which is why I have 5.3 hours played.

reviewText: This game is the very worst possible evolution of the Free to Play model. Hotbars locked behind a paywall, bag slots locked behind a paywall. Anything resembling the art style of the game in  a set of armor, paywall. And these aren't tiny 1 dollar or 2 dollar paywalls, this crap is like 30 dollars at the least! Some things can be unlocked for 5 or 6 dollars, but each item is priced just high enough to send you up to the next 10 dollar incriment of the in game currency! Everyone in the game is decked out in high end outfits and you look like you are a character from another friggin game when your free clothes expire. Oh yeah, you pay 30 bucks for an outfit and it has a licence that expires most fo the time if you don't pay double for it! Don't get me started on premium emotes, stances and PVP gear. All around this game would be a blast if there wasn't a pay wall jammed into every nook and cranny of the game to the point it becomes totally unplayable. I would gladly throw a dollar on an outfit, maybe 5, but this pay model is off the charts ludicrous!

reviewText:
At first, I used to be all for this game.

It was great. It was fun. I made friends. There was some semblance of balace in the PVP.

All was good with the world.

But over time, with the addition of new characters, it became increasingly pay-to-win.
The devs don't care. They're getting their precious dollars out of the NA playerbase while the KR playerbase gets all of the goodies.

Want a good Action MMO? Go play Dungeon Fighter Online. Pass on this. It may be enjoyable at first, but rest assured that you'll either fall into the Pay-to-Win trap, or quit out of disgust.

reviewText:
It's an enjoyable game, it really is, but I have to hate on the fact that this game is very 'Pay to Win'. You have to buy yourself the upgraded job/class for 2USD, (which in reality really is not much),  you also get some nice items for doing it, but those items last ~10 days, which ticks me off. If I was allowed to keep those items I'd be happier, but alas, I cannot. It is quite grindy, but what MMORPG isn't?
All in all, I recommend it if you have a few bucks in your wallet and you're willing to spend it for a 10-ish day bonus costume and some extra skills, even without the job advancement the game can be fun, but sadly as it is highly P2W I cannot recommend it.

If you're going to win me over, the least you could do is let me keep those job advancement items, like c'mon.

Note: I have not played very long, nor have I tried the PvP.

reviewText:
To start off, you have to almost buy everything in the game including skill slots, and you only get 4 before paying. you also have to buy backpack expansions, which i can see reasonable, but the problem is they give you crap before buying expansions.

Buying things with in game money are basically pointless except for  a variety of accessories, because by the time you get up to the level where you can use the weapon you can buy, you don't even need to buy it anymore.

There are 2 upsides to this game though, the combat, and the characters. The combat is a hack and slash button mashing of z & x. Although, over a long period of time, the combat starts getting boring, knowing the only time you get more combat moves is when you get your class change, I am going to rate the combat a 6/10.

Each character has  their own story, weapons, and combat style, but some of the different characters have the same class change stats, which imo, is kinda lame, but like i said, they all have their own combat style.

The maps in the game start to get redundant and lack imagination, because some of their maps are the same, but flipped, or with a different climate and time.

I think the thing I hate most about this game is the stamina, you have stamina on every character, and when its empty, you can't do any dungeon quests and you have to wait until 3:00am to play again, which makes you think that the creators don't want you to play the game.

My rating for this game is a 6/10. I do reccomend to people who are new to PC gaming. Its still fun at time and i would continue playing it because they are always adding new items and characters that get enjoyable.

reviewText: I actually played this game a while ago, and I have to say, it looks really cool. It's not mind blowing, but for a vividly colored anime world, it's really nice. And the gameplay is innovative too. Sure, you can just mash te keyboard and swing wildly, but if you want to really survive, especailly if you're going solo rather than in a party of online players, then you WILL master all the key combinations in order to dish out powerful combo moves.\nHowever, as you get higher and level, the pressure to spend real money gets higher and higher, or maybe it's because I didn't have people to play with.\nHowever, the game is still fun, killing monsters is satisfying, and the boss battles are so incredibly awesome and epic, you'd think Nintendo thought them up! So if you have lots of friends, and don't mind spending real money (mayeb 30 dollars), then this is the game for you.

reviewText:
I played this game since the release of grand archer and wind sneeker.
Where to start, the game can claim it's different than most game that are around today, which is true, not many do the gameplay that elsword does.
Now where this game falls apart on you........some may tell you that leveling up is easy in this game, that's not true, it's only easy if you are below level 30 or so, after that you will have to repeat the same dungeons over and over and over and over and over until you run out of stamina, and which you find yourself having to not even level up ONCE and then you will have to repeat the process again the next day.
EXP boosting does exist, but there is a catch, you either grind for a few days to get certain items to get exp boosting items, which will take a while, or you can just buy it with real money, which for the people with no means of getting real money or using them for an online game, that is really unfair. Why you would need to boost exp to level up only once and which still takes a long time to do is beyond me.
You won't fully enjoy the game unless you're within the level range of 50-70, which again, why would I need to be that high of a level to enjoy a game to its fullest. I'm not just talking about certain things being blocked off to you if you do not reach level requirement by the way.
Even so though, I'm not sure your attention span will even want to go that high of a level if you're not into grind fest, which this game is a HUGE grind fest. Example, early in the game, it will only take you around 2-4 hours to get from level 1 to level 15 easily, at first you're like, This isn't too hard if the game is like this all the time." which you would be right......if the game worked like that in the first place...but when comes the time of around let's say....level 36
date: it will take you a day to jump to level 37.\nNow

reviewText:
Ok, I'm going to say it. Elsword USED to be Pay2Win. Back during the 2014-2015 Elsword days, you'd had to sacrifice some of that cash in order to buy the extended skill slot and a ring of fury. Now, those items are buyable from the board. The economy thankfully deflated sometime ago and Ice Burner sets are easier to obtain compared to how they were back then.

Now here's the problem with Elsword.

PvP is STILL unbalanced. Winning/Losing a match is usually decided in this order: Gear > Class > Actual Skill. I find this odd since Ereda Island actually normalizes damage, so why is PvP not like this?

I still like Elsword, but I'm going to give this game a negative review since there's no mixed reccomendation on Steam. The community is also something to take in account, which I have mixed feelings about. The community had changed so much from when I started back in 2013 that I can't help but feel saddened over it. If you give this game a shot, take caution.

Ok so here is the game from a newbs run through

Starting out this game looks great controls are good everything looks good to go.
Then later on you start doing dungies with other people and its just a bunch of people smushed together spaming abilitys and wacking a boss.... you can't even see your person there is no challenge there is no block or dodge in this game you can jump but I dont see the point since you can just spam the boss and knock it down or stun it over and over...

So all you have to choose from is doing the same lower lvl quest you have been doing over an over or go into another dungie for the 4th or 5th time spamming ♥♥♥♥ in a mess of non sense.

The game looks great but the gameplay, quest system, and fake ♥♥♥ combo system are complete ♥♥♥♥!!

reviewText:
Elsword is a Korean MMO beat 'em up in 2&1/2D. Here the player controls one out of nine (as of now) characters to level them up and defeat hordes of monsters while progressing through the story.

Unfortunately, I already ran into problems at the level of trying to register an account. Apparently their confirmation emails can only reach certain domains, like GMail. Before I figured it out, however, I already linked my Steam account to the one that I couldn't activate and had to wait a few days for it to expire before being able to re-link it to a working one. During that time my enthusiasm for this game died out completely and it basically set the tone for my playthrough of this. If the creators fail on the level of account creation... That's just not a good sign.

Once we enter the game, the first thing that comes to us is the fact that the English localization team decided to leave the Korean voice acting intact, which is quite unusual for most English versions of Asian games. I personally don't mind them, it's just that it was kinda hard to understand what they were actually saying, me being used more to Japanese.

Speaking of that, I usually like to mod my games to some extent, so I managed to find (by complete accident) a mod which replaces the voice packs with those from different languages, so for example I could try getting Japanese ones into the game, which would keep it somewhat climactic yet I would be able to make out some words out of it... eeexcept the NA version (which is apparently the Steam one) changed the voiceover format from .wav to .ogg. For no reason.

Another thing that stroke me as kind of odd is the fact that you need to name your characters. I mean, it would be okay if they were just classes to be chosen from and you could customize their appearance to some extent, but they are all named characters with unique backstories. Why do you have to call yourself something like Eve Clone no. 99"? Why can't you just give your account as a whole a single nickname to use for all of your characters?

I stretched out this rant long enough
date: so let's get to the main part of the review.\nThe anime-style cell-shaded graphics look okay. They aren't anything spectacular
recommended: and can kind of make your eyes tired
hoursPlayed: especially the low-res textures. While it did take over three years for the game to leave Asia
voteText: it still came out later than for example Team Fortress 2.\n\nIn the sound department

votesFunny: your skills
commentsCount: obtain better gear

Your chances of dying at anything that isn't at least a mini-boss are basically nonexistant provided you do dodge their blows. You can use special skills which are usually very powerful hits or autocombos akin to supers from fighting games
column20: burning MP in the process which can be gained back by hitting enemies and slowly replenishes itself over time. Also
column21: you get only three item quickslots and four skill quickslots. You can double those amounts... by paying real money. Imagine if in an MMORPG

column23: and guess what: after reaching certain levels

column39: with the only difference being that your character isn't a soulless mime who just listens to what others have to say. Most of the quests are your basic "kill X enemies"

column41: some quests even outright tell you to beat the same dungeon multiple times. Let the obvious grind begin!\n\nWhat also bothers me is the fact that higher difficulties
column44: i.e. enemies' stats are inflated to higher levels but they fight the same way and it only takes longer to beat them down. Besides that

column46: and that's about it.\n\nAnother thing is that
column47: despite it being technically a beat 'em up
column48: it still has accuracy and evasion stats. Why does the RNG get to decide whether or not you hit the monster when your weapon visibly makes physical contact with it?\n\nSince this is a beat 'em up
column49: I wanted to play it on a gamepad
column50: but this game's support for it is honestly pretty mediocre. You still need your mouse to get through menus
column51: and the number of skill and item quickslots (without buying the additional ones!) already exceeds the number of buttons a PS controller (which I'm using) posseses. So you'll have to reach your hand out to the keyboard often.\n\nI can't say much about PvP since I'm not interested in it
column52: but I can already tell that it's not fun. The game allows you to take your gear and its stat boosts into PvP matches
column53: and while it does get "normalized" to not allow min-maxers to build something ridiculously broken and impossible to counter

column58: so until now it was only the negatives. What are the positives? Well... the wide variety of characters and their possible classes allow for a lot of experimentation. The bosses are still pretty fun to fight against. There is also a Stamina system which is supposed to lock your character out of dungeons for the duration of the day if their Stamina gets completely depleted
column59: but it shouldn't happen unless you've been playing for a few hours straight. The character arts also look absolutely amazing. (Too bad they aren't nearly as detailed in the game itself.)\n\nMy final verdict? The cons far outweigh the pros. There are restrictions on things that shouldn't even be restricted and certain solutions to things that are just plain stupid. I can't recommend it unless you play it more as a side thing for fun

reviewText:
Imagine a game with the potential to be a better smash bros. but gets bogged down by trash balance, poor design, korean p2w, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ customer support, overpriced cash shop, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ devs and horrible power creep.

All of this is from the perspective of someone who's played thousands of hours, on steam and off steam. Never spent any money on Elsword (thank goodness.)

Pros:
- Core game is actually great.

Cons:
- Horrible balance
- ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and invasive anticheat (gameguard hates when you try to play other games at the same time)
- Customer support is either bots, unresponsive, or tells you to reinstall the game.
- PvE has more effect on PvP than actual skill (levels and grinding gear)
- Cash has more effect on PvP than actual skill (buying your way to better gear)
- PvE is mindless repetitive grind
- Extremely pricey cash shop (ex. 30-40 dollars for a ♥♥♥♥ing costume)
- ♥♥♥♥♥♥ netcode. (there's permanent desync and 0 latency compensation)
- Bugs, some of which have existed for years without fix
- Framerate is tied to animation speed (which is really important for hitstuns)
- Framerate is capped differently on different OS (83 on win7, 75 on win8)
- Win 8 has trouble running the game and has nasty input delay on top of the framerate cap
- Texture quality and model quality is garbage by today's standards and especially for the amount of RAM the game uses
- Massive Power Creep (new chars/classes were much better than the old ones)
- Most of the PvP community think they're amazing when they're complete trash.
- Ranks mean nothing due to massive inflation.
- Game mechanics that reward poor play over skill (gaining more mana when getting hit rather than hitting someone, dealing damage to someone for being hit)

TL;DR: Don't
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Its so good, but so bad\n\nElsword online is one of the best, if not the best side scrolling RPG beat em ups you will ever play on steam.The characters are colorful, the dungeons are fun, and the PVP is amazing..to an extent. That being said i've been playing elsword since 2011 and many things have yet to change, It is so pay to win that when you get to a certian point to where all of the dungeons are clear and all you want to do is PVP or redo the dungeons, you cant do so without having to buy a set with real money. The character customazation they so proudly show you every single loading screen is only possible with the use of money. And the PVP is as easy as who spent the most money on gear (from lvl 65+)  For years now elsword has been doing this nonsense, and maybe you might get a costume drop every other week after you grind the same dungeon 50 times or mabye get a OP mount for a day after you log on for a week, but regardless Elsword is still an unbalenced, pay to win game masked with colorful characters and a couple hours fun of fun pvp.

reviewText:
I've got to say, I played this game around the time if first came out (before Steam) and it doesn't feel as though it's changed much. Since I've picked it up again I've come to realize why I stopped playing. It's fun if you wanna mess around with some free 2d platformer type action to kill some time, but beyond that I do NOT reccomend this as the game for you.

The shop is the only way to win and leveling up becomes a tedious grind after you hit around 28-32. The characters/classes are cool and can be fun, but after you get your final job" class at 35 you stagnate and you stick to the same old combos for the rest of the game.

It's free though so I suppose you don't have much to lose."

I want to put this game into a pespective anyone who wants to download it can understand. So the levelling process gets monotonous. They have gauge that slowly depletes and makes it so that evetually you will run out of stamina nad be unable to run dungeons. Unless it's the weekend. BS.

reviewText:
DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME, I REPEAT!

1. The developers are so desperate, that there was 2 events that leveled every one up to lv70, just to attract players. meaning that if u play now... no one is going to be playing these low level dungeons and dont even talk about trying to pvp.

2. The pvp in this game is quite unpolished, tons of mechanics but the match making is screwed up, u pretty much get matched up to complete randoms, hence they can be lv 80(the max lv) and ur a lv10

3.Extremely grindy, takes 20 years to grind a few ED (in game currency) which can be used to purchase stuff

4. Super bad currency! RIP OFF, KOG games wanted money so bad that one piece of custume costs 5 dollars.

5. Pay to win

6. Trying to buy stuff with in game cash (ED) is not possible, one custume costs 100 million ED and u earn 5 k each dungeon which takes 15 mins.....

7. JUST DONT WASTE UR TIME DOWNLOADING IT!

reviewText:
Is Not like use to. you are better  off playing something else.

Is the game fun?: Yes only to a certain limit.

Is the PVP Good?: HELL YEA! for low levels in 20-40.. After you pass level 50 - 80 it turns into a 100% pay to win  game.

Is it balance?: No... After S1 and S2 half way, The newst characters are broken and the Revamp is making it worst.

Is the game Actualy free to play?: Yes actualy! Pve is fair but Sadly if you wanna get into pvp and do good ( you really don't need skill any more to play pvp..) than no! $$$ all the way.

How is the cash shop?: Customes are over prices and can only be retrade once.. Unless is a IB custome witch cost over 120-500$ dollars.

I have made over 12 Characters on Elsword and spent over 600$ on this game, sadly in steam only show 150+ hours but im pretty sure i have way more than that. From experice on reaching SSS on my GM BM BH and DC i can tell you the that worst thing about this game is the PVP community and economy.  Wanna play this game for the PVE? GO ahead is actualy pretty fun PVE! Get a hook on some friends start a skype and PVE all night! Just don't touch PVP.

reviewText:
I have played this game quite a bit with the non-Steam version of it, and I have to say at its heart it is a good game.
However, it is also a terrible game, that you shouldn't play on the NA (North American) Server, but on the KR (Korean) Server due to some major issues with the NA server that will never ever be fixed.

To be at least able to run dungeons to your fullest potential later on, you must at least invest 9$ to gain access to 4 extra skill slots, because without you will only be able to used 4 skills opposed to a grand total of 8 with the B slot (Skill Slot B). To be able to compete in combat against other players when your character reaches a high level, you must at least invest around 30$ generally, this will cover the B slot so you can use your character to its fullest potential (9$), a costume to wear and enchant for stats that are needed to compete without being at a disadvantage (20$ total for a PERMANENT -not 30 day duration- hair, top piece -shirt-, bottom piece -pants-, gloves, and shoes). Do not say that you can use the so-called Free-KChing (Premium currency used to purchase B-slot and costumes amongst many other things that are sort of required to get the most out of this game)" surveys to get all of your KChing

reviewText:
Strong suits+Fairly good-looking for its genre
+Customization options are pretty good
+Active NA/DE/SEA communities, at least last I checked

Where it blows-Steam defaults to NA servers, UK server is dead

-Said P2W elements will cost an arm and a leg
-Equipment with time limit, what's up with that?
-Even the daily grind/your playtime is hampered by the stamina bar
-Gameplay tends to get dumbed down to button-mashing

reviewText: Ok ignore the time, I play elsword off of steam.\nElsword, without a doubt, is one of my favorite games in general.  Why is that?  To be honest, I don't even know.  Most of the community is toxic as ♥♥♥♥, people not from NA like to raid our server making it even laggier than it should be, those who pay definetly have an edge over f2p players, and in PvP (imo the selling point of this game) your rank is no longer a direct correlation of your skill level. If you can ignore these, Elsword is still a great game.  You can have stylish af combos, the effects in the game are pretty well done, and thanks to the variety of classes in the game, (9 characters with 3 classes each, soon one more will be added with two classes), gameplay is varied.  Tbh, if KoG can stop making this game super ♥♥♥♥, and the freemium in this game was toned down a bit,  This could by far be one of the best games in our generation.  But until KoG pulls their ♥♥♥♥ together, I can't in my right mind reccomend this to random people.  If I know you though, play with me I need people to play with ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

reviewText: All in All, Elsword is a really, really fun game. I've been playing for a couple of years and love the new characters that come out. If there were any downsides it would be the money it costs to permanently buy costumes and costume pieces as well as mounts and pets and the pvp that can put you up against a high level players. Besides that it's really fun and there are cool events that allow you to get these items I mentioned above for free although it usually involves alot of grinding.

reviewText:
Stamina system: I can see why they would put this is but I believe people should be able to play as much as they want.
Quick slots: Having to pay for quick slots set b is absolutely unreasonable
Micro purchase overload:
1) paying money to get k-ching so you can buy good potions since the others do not heal enough
2) Fossil and ice burners are useless it's costs k-ching to buy them to have a slim chance of getting something good.
3) items cost more than they're worth to buy them permanently and not temporary.
4) Player market has idiots that sell items for astronomic prices.
5) Ed (the game currency not the paid currency) is worthless since anything good is premium currency
6) It's almost as if the game punishes you for being in a party
7) it's $100 for 10,000 k-ching use your money on something else. steam has a lot of good games that can give you hours of fun for a cheaper price and better graphics.

It's not that the game is bad because it isn't however the Greed of the makers has ruined it, some stuff like the premium shop is understandable but everything costing money it's disgusting. they don't care about their community they just want your money it seems and it's a sad thing because the game could do so much better if they were more humble and connected to their fan base and community. Not even facebook games have so many micro payments.

What the game could and should be
Game: 8/10

What it is
Game 3/10

reviewText:
Alright, i finnaly have a max lvl character and ive spent enough time in this game to write a worthwhile review. Ill split my review in 2 parts; PVP and PVE, Aka. Players versus players and Player versus enemies (dongeons), which are the 2 parts of the experience this game as to offer.
---------------------------------------
Lets start with PVE.
PVE consist of a set of dongeons, you go to the dongeon corresponding to your level, get some quests done, kill some bosses, nothing really ground breaking. The part that i hate about PVE in this game is that its REALLY REALLY easy, your party will just steam roll everything even on hard difficulty, later it gets more challanging but thats 100h into the game (if you make it that far) and even then its repetitive as hell anyway.
TL;DR PVE is easy, grindy and boring
---------------------------------------
Now for PVP.
PVP is quite simple, you go in 1v1 2v2 or 3v3 and try to kill the enemy, nothing fancy or complex going on here, you kill people, which is totally fine, not all games need 12 pvp modes. But it gets ugly rather quickly, heres a list of whats wrong with pvp:
1: The ranked system is based of your total win rate and ignore your level totally so having a lvl 40 face a lvl 70 happens really often and of course the lvl 40 gets pummeled.
2: PVP is pay2win, not by a lot, but still is, let me explain. You are limited to 4 skills at all times, however you can pay 10$ to unlock a second skillset and have 8 instead, effectively giving you twice the flexibility in combat. If you want to go far in PVP you better have dat 10 bucks.
3: Random items, there are some random items that spawn in the pvp arena which grants various buffs and bonuses, theres no problem here so far. The problem arise that you cant turn them off in RANKED pvp. Adding a element of randomness to a RANKED match is just rage inducing to say the least.
4: Lag, nothing much to say here, it lag and that sucks.
5: Balance issues; Some classes are just flat out broken and little is done in order to balance them.
TL:DR PVP is pay2win, laggy and unbalanced.

reviewText:
+Overall-
This game is awesome Its a fighting game an a MMO all in one. I personally love playing RF because you punch everything but it has a variety of play styles for everbody for example Deadly Chaser a job class for chung is the Guile of Elsword an Elsword is kinda the Ryu. Not only does it contibute to the fighting Genre of fans but also anime fans because it has that feel but not too much to make both sides even.

+Classes-
So basically how it goes is you pick a character instead of a class (like a fighting game) an you proceed to level up the character and once you reach lvl 15 you get your first job change an after you reach 35 I believe you get your 2nd job change which is going to be your character from then on. each character will end up having 3 job classes and each one will be extremely different from the others, I'll use Raven as an example.

-Reckless Fist is basically a character where he can take hits but aslo dish out damage aswell an uses his nasod arm instead of his sword doing high magical damage with super armor most of the time.

-Blade Master focues around using his blade with very fast attacks before his opponent can but is very vulnerable to magical and a little bit to physical but he avoids this by being very mobile.

-Veteran Commander is a cross between ranged and close combat basically a shoto character in a fighting game he isnt very tanky but he has good combos, good mobility and has high damaging specials making him a really dangerous class.

Overall the class system is really good because there is something for everyone, If you like a powerhouse but like to be a little tanky go for Raven, if you like zoneing your oppoenent go Rena or Aisha, You wanna be in the opponents face almost all the time being very mobile and have good reach Ara, You just wanna go on full dmg not caring about defense Add is a good character to do that awell. Overall there is so much variety right now in elsword everyone can find a character.

+Gamplay

Now this is the thing every person in a fighting game cares about and also in MMOs the gameplay.
-PVP
right now Elsword has a balanced system after a certain amount of hits a persons KDR(Knock Down Rate) will go up an make them fall ending the combo, but people can work around this and do something called a KD reset where they hit the oppoent in the air most of the time and bring them back down before they fall to the ground allowing them to continue the combo. Now before you think the first hit decides the match, MP (Mana Points) is a resource which everyone has and once you reach a hundred you can hold Light or Heavy attack and Mana Break forcing youself to fall ending the combo but like any other fighting game being on the ground is a big dis-advantage so stay mobile is key in elsword there is no true block button aside from one of Elsword's actives(I mean the character not the game, confusing yes I know). But like most fighting games it comes down to skill who can utilize his kit better then the other player, but like all other PVP games there is something OP once in awhile right now Ara and Elesis are very strong character being very mobile an sometimes having super armor and MAJOR damage moves one example to prove this is that in all big heard tournaments in Elsword usally Ara's always win because one of her jobs is insanley powerful. With the recently added character Add he is probably the most damaging character once he gets his conditions set but he has 0 to none defense being half healthed usally in one combo. But everything is usally patched or buffs are given to other character to balance it out, Elsword does a pretty good job about this so dont judge the game by a few characters.

-PVE
This is something Elsword is minorly known for but before you go saying, I side scroller? Thats probably so easy!". You are wrong because in dungens later in the game become really challenging making you follow mechanics so you cant have an easy time. It also has insane raid bosses that have tricky patterns to memorize making it a real challenge
date: also seasonal raid bossess so you get something new most of the time. I will say that some dungens can be done pretty easy if you got or bought a "Mount" basically these things only use is for dungens doing insane damage for a set amount of time but it doesnt entirley break the game one because they are expensive and they only have 100 stamina an may only last around 5-6 minutes at a time. Overall Elsword PVP isnt boring because it most of the time comes up with something knew almost every month or so actually quicker then that sometimes
recommended:
it is in no way easy or boring.

+Graphics

They have simple graphics that look good

+Final

reviewText: Look, this game is pretty good. I found myself addicted to it only to realize how terrible the support team was. In PVP you'll find yourself being frustrated by hackers and laggers (yeah lag is a big deal in this game) rather than people with tons of in-game cash items. Play at your own discretion.

reviewText:
I have played and enjoyed my fair share of hours in this game, that being said the microcharge for everything they can.
You can buy a lot of advantages so it can be quite unbalanced for the true Free-to-play player.

Examples:
Magic Necklace - Improves your mana aquisation by +30% when attacking or being attacked. 800KC/8$
Full Costume Packages - Can be socketed for additional stats 2390KC/23.9$
B-slot - Allows you to use 4 more skills in PvE and PvP - 900KC/9$
Item mall rings - Adds additional skill points to some of your skills (depending on what ring you choose) 700KC/7$

Items can be gifted so you CAN aquire theese items by buying them from players who sell their KC, but the economy of this game is so broken and the prices are absolutely ridicoulus. Futhermore, it still requires someone to actually pay for and support this kind of business.

What makes this game worth playing is that it is the only one of it's kind out there for anime-style slice-em up fast paced PvE and PvP, had there been any other game similar to this, with better balance of prices and general management of the game I would have choosen that any day.

GAMEPLAY: Gameplay is very stale and repetative, people say that it is what you can expect from an Korean MMO" but it doesen't change the fact that it's a grind-fest. In order to level you are required to spam the same dungeons over and over again
